newsitem.title: USA: BASKETBALL-SWOOPES PLAYS FIVE MINUTES IN RETURN.
newsitem.headline: BASKETBALL-SWOOPES PLAYS FIVE MINUTES IN RETURN.

text.p: After waiting out a year and a pregnancy to make her WNBA debut, five minutes with no shot attempts and no rebounds was enough for Sheryl Swoopes.

Swoopes, the Houston Comets forward who missed the team's first 19 games, made her first appearance of the season in Thursday's 74-70 victory over the Phoenix Mercury, just over six weeks after giving birth.

The 6-foot (1.83 metres) Swoopes was one of the stars of the 1996 U.S. Olympic gold medal team, but that was the last time she played a game. She gave birth to a baby boy, Jordan Eric Jackson, on June 25 and joined the team for practice for the first time on July 30.

"I feel really good," said the 26-year-old Swoopes, "nervous at first after not playing organised basketball for over a year. I knew it would take a little time to warm up and get the butterflies out. It doesn't matter how many minutes I play, it just felt good to be a part of the team tonight."
She had set Saturday's game against Los Angeles as the target date for her return, but decided to play this game to prepare for that contest, a nationally televised game.
Swoopes -- a Brownfield, Texas, native who led Texas Tech to the 1993 national collegiate championship, scoring a finals-record 47 points -- was one of the first two players to sign with the WNBA.
